references: O'Farrell, M.J. and A.R. Blaustein. 1972. Ecological distribution of sagebrush voles, Lagurus curtatus, in south-central Washington. Journal of Mammalogy, 53:632-636.
Verts, B.J., and L. Carraway. 1998. Land Mammals of Oregon. University of California Press, Berkeley, CA.
Hall, Raymond E. 1946. Mammals of Nevada University of California Press, Berkely and Los Angeles, California.
Dunmire, W. W. 1961. Breeding season of three rodents on White Mountain, California. Journal of Mammalolgy,  42:489-493.
Carroll, L.E. and H. H. Genoways. 1980. Lagurus curtatus. Mammalalian Species No. 124: 1–6. American Society of Mammalogists, pp. 1-6.
Wilson, D.E. and S. Ruff. 1999. The Smithsonian book of North American mammals. Washington, DC, Smithsonian Inst. Press. 750 p.
O'Farrell, M. J. 1974. Seasonal activity patterns of rodents in a sagebrush community. Journal of Mammalogy, 55:809-823.
habitat_description:
Southwest/Northwest:
The species “is generally restricted to semi-arid prairies, rolling hills, or brushy canyons, with loose, well-drained soil (although the surface may be rocky).  Vegetation is usually dominated by sagebrush (Artemisia spp.) and bunch-grasses, especially crested wheatgrass (Agropyron spp.)..”  “Rabbitbrush (Chrysothamnus spp.) may also be a dominant component of the vegetation…” (Carroll and Genoways 1980).  In Nevada, nearly always found in Sagebrush (Artemisia tridentata), typically widely spaced and about 2 1/2 tall (Hall 1946).  Atypical habitats lack sagebrush and are dominated by grasses and annuals (Carroll and Genoways 1980, Hall 1946).  Elevation range in Nevada is 5800 - 10,000 feet (1770- 3050 m; Hall 1946), and in California maximum elevation is 3780 m (CDFG 2003).
From California Wildlife Habitat Relationship System life history write-up:
"In California, occurs in the Great Basin regions of northern Inyo Co., Mono Co., and the 
eastern parts of Sierra, Plumas, Lassen, and Modoc cos. Populations fluctuate, but generally 
are highest in sagebrush, bitterbrush, and low sage habitats. The sagebrush vole may be 
locally common to abundant in perennial grassland, pinyon-juniper, and alpine dwarf-shrub 
habitats. Found up to 3780 m (12,100 ft) in California (Dunmire 1961). Distribution is tied 
closely to sagebrush and perennial grassland (O'Farrell 1972)."
In Oregon, this species has been found in abandoned pocket gopher burrows on loose rock or sandy soils within crested wheatgrass, cheat grass, green and gray rabbit-brush, and big sagebrush among scattered juniper and bitter-brush habitats. In Washington this species was found rarely below 305 meters and most frequently between 305-610 meters (and > 910m) in Artemisa-Agropyron associations (O'Farrell and Blaustein 1972, Verts and Carraway 1998).
